title: Waskerley Way Walking and Cycle Route

nearby.description: Pow Hill Country Park and Derwent Reservoir

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Waskerley Way
images.caption: This disused railway - the Stanhope and Tyne Railway was built to serve the needs of the Weardale lead and iron ore mining industries in the 19th century; the section in the photo is part of the nearly level summit section at 400 metres, the highest section of standard gauge railway in Britain. In the trees in the distance is Waskerley village.

images.title: John Armitstead / Waskerley Way
images.caption: A group of cyclists on the trail in the summer of 2004. The railway reached an altitude of 509m (1670ft), and was the highest standard-gauge railway in Britain.

images.title: M J Richardson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Waskerley Way by Hown's Farm. Straight on for the old railway path, right for the bunkhouse.

images.title: Cyclists on the Waskerley Way by Oliver Dixon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cyclists on mountain bikes on Muggleswick Moor.

images.title: M J Richardson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: NCN 7 signpost at Lydgate. Where the Waskerley Way, the Consett and Sunderland Path, the Derwent Valley Path and the Lanchester Path meet.

images.title: Heather moorland beside Waskerley Way by Trevor Littlewood, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Heather moorland beside the path

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Waskerley Reservoir (north-east corner)
images.caption: Waskerley Reservoir (north-east corner). The reservoir is popular with birdwatchers

images.title: Helen Wilkinson / Waskerley Way
images.caption: A car park on the the Way, a bridleway on the line of an old mineral railway.

description: This is a shared cycling and walking path that follows the route of the old Stanhope and Tyne Railway line. The path starts near Consett and runs to Weather Hill passing through woodland and open moorland. You will also pass the delightful Smiddy Shaw Reservoir , Hisehope Reservoir, Waskerley Reservoir and Tunstall Reservoir near the village of Wolsingham .
